dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, we've been looking into some really, like, surprising information about past vaccine efforts, specifically around HIV.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, we've been looking into some really, like, surprising information about past vaccine efforts, specifically around H I V.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, um, it's pretty wild. This initiative from, like, a decade ago, was actually celebrated as a success because it *decreased* risk for *some* men...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, um, it's pretty wild. This initiative from, like, a decade ago, was actually celebrated as a success because it decreased risk for some men...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers warn of a cautionary tale from efforts to create an HIV vaccine over a decade ago, where a promising vaccine candidate actually increased the risk of some men catching the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but the big kicker is that it actually, overall, *increased* the risk of HIV transmission for others. It's, like, a total paradox.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but the big kicker is that it actually, overall, increased the risk of H I V transmission for others. It's, like, a total paradox.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers warn of a cautionary tale from efforts to create an HIV vaccine over a decade ago, where a promising vaccine candidate actually increased the risk of some men catching the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And the core of it, the mechanism they used, was this fully functional virus called adenovirus 5, or Ad5, as a vector.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And the core of it, the mechanism they used, was this fully functional virus called adenovirus five, or A D five, as a vector.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vaccine made use of a modified virus called adenovirus 5 (Ad5) as a vector to transport some of HIVs genetic material into the body.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. It was basically, like, a delivery truck for HIV's genetic material. And, get this, despite the *increased* risk, the NIH initially recommended its continued use.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. It was basically, like, a delivery truck for H I V's genetic material. And, get this, despite the increased risk, the N I H initially recommended its continued use.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Exactly how the vaccine increased the risks of HIV transmission is unknown, but a conference convened by the National Institutes of Health recommended against further use of Ad5 as a vector in HIV vaccines (Dr. Anthony Fauci was lead author of the paper outlining this position.)

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, by the way, Dr. Anthony Fauci *vehemently* opposed, for good reason, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, by the way, Doctor Anthony Fauci vehemently opposed, for good reason, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a conference convened by the National Institutes of Health recommended against further use of Ad5 as a vector in HIV vaccines (Dr. Anthony Fauci was lead author of the paper outlining this position.)

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Now, the interesting thing is, Ad5 isn't in vaccines like J&J or AstraZeneca for COVID-19, right? They *avoided* it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Now, the interesting thing is, A D five isn't in vaccines like J and J or AstraZeneca for C O V I D-nineteen, right? They avoided it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some of the leading candidates for a Covid-19 vaccine, including those from Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca, use adenoviruses as vectors. There is no evidence that those vectors increase the risk of HIV infection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, thank goodness. But, um, there *are* other COVID vaccine candidates out there, like two in Phase 3 trials in Russia and Pakistan, that *do* use Ad5.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, thank goodness. But, um, there are other C O V I D vaccine candidates out there, like two in Phase three trials in Russia and Pakistan, that do use A D five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ad5 is used as a vector in some Covid-19 vaccines Science identifies four such candidates that are currently undergoing clinical trials in various countries around the world, including the U.S., with two in large scale phase 3 trials ongoing in Russia and Pakistan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And here's where it gets really concerning. The original researchers, for the HIV vaccine, they were apparently pretty unconcerned about Ad5's role in increasing HIV risk for vulnerable groups.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And here's where it gets really concerning. The original researchers, for the H I V vaccine, they were apparently pretty unconcerned about A D five's role in increasing H I V risk for vulnerable groups.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers stressed the need to understand the role Ad5 might play in increasing the risks of HIV in vulnerable populations before developing and deploying vaccines using the vector...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unconcerned? That's, that's almost unbelievable. They even suggested informed consent documents *shouldn't* reflect the literature on Ad5's risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unconcerned? That's, that's almost unbelievable. They even suggested informed consent documents shouldn't reflect the literature on A D five's risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...adding that informed consent documents should reflect the considerable literature on the risk of HIV acquisition with Ad5 vectors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And there's actually strong evidence showing these Ad5 vectors *do* increase the risk of HIV infection.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And there's actually strong evidence showing these A D five vectors do increase the risk of H I V infection.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers warn of a cautionary tale from efforts to create an HIV vaccine over a decade ago, where a promising vaccine candidate actually increased the risk of some men catching the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, given all that, you'd think people would be really cautious now, especially with COVID vaccines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, given all that, you'd think people would be really cautious now, especially with C O V I D vaccines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, here's a quote that just, like, floored me. Lawrence Corey, who co-leads the COVID-19 prevention network for the NIH...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, here's a quote that just, like, floored me. Lawrence Corey, who co-leads the C O V I D-nineteen prevention network for the N I H...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow, that's a big name.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow, that's a big name.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He told Science, "If he were in a sub-Saharan African country, where there's a high prevalence of HIV, I would pick an Ad5 vector when there are many other alternative choices."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He told Science, If he were in a sub-Saharan African country, where there's a high prevalence of H I V, I would pick an A D five vector when there are many other alternative choices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lawrence Corey, one of the authors who now co-leads the Covid-19 prevention network in the U.S. that is testing vaccines on behalf of the NIH, told Science that if he were in a sub-Saharan African country, where theres a high prevalence of HIV, I dont see why I would pick an Ad5 vector (vaccine) when there are many other alternative choices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: What?! Even knowing the risks? That just sounds like, um, a recipe for "vaccine apartheid" to me, frankly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What?! Even knowing the risks? That just sounds like, um, a recipe for vaccine apartheid to me, frankly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really raises some uncomfortable questions about ethics and global health equity, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really raises some uncomfortable questions about ethics and global health equity, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. A lot to unpack there, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. A lot to unpack there, for sure.
